title.rendered: Find Rooms For Rent In Los Angeles

content.rendered:
Los Angeles in California is the City of Dreams, the City of Angels, a city blessed and cursed with a glorious dream and façade of hopes. It is the best city for experiencing the quintessential endless summer in Southern California. With an added layer of glitter sprinkled on top of its sprawling expanse! All this makes it one of the best places to live in! And Roomi can help you with it! Here’s a detailed guide on everything you need to know from best neighborhoods and studio apartments to rooms for rent in Los Angeles.

Getting to know Los Angeles

The city is made up of so much – distinct lifestyles and communities intertwined, fraying at the edges. This is the city where dreams are visualized and come to life! The beautiful sunsets, palm trees, the beaches and view of the skyline from studio apartments make Los Angeles one of the most beautiful cities to live in.

Finding rooms for rent & studio apartments in Los Angeles

Let’s look at the Los Angeles housing market trends and forecasts for 2021. This will help you make informed decisions on how to live in L.A. and where. As with most other things during this pandemic, apartment hunting is best done online. Based on the supply-demand dynamics, the real estate appreciation rate in Los Angeles is predicted to remain strong in 2021.

Rooms For Rent Available in Los Angeles

Top Neighborhoods in Los Angeles

  • Echo Park: Just north of Chinatown and Downtown L.A. lies Echo Park, a budding area with a reputation of a vibrant and funky neighborhood. Living in Los Angeles’ studio apartments you can enjoy its lively nightlife scene. If you like scenic parks and outdoor activities, Echo Park is the one for you!
  • Santa Monica & Venice: These areas offer a beach view life, so what more could you ask for while looking for rooms for rent in Los Angeles? Additionally, you’ll strike a balance between having a relaxed lifestyle and at the same time, first-class amenities.
  • West Hollywood: If you’re looking for a quiet, suburban existence then West Hollywood is not for you. Trendy and bustling, it’s LA’s LGBTQ+ capital showcases some of the liveliest nightlife the city has to offer. Vibrancy at its best!

Average rent in Los Angeles

As the second-largest city in the United States, Los Angeles allures residents from across the country and even internationally. It is a hub for directors, actors and artists to pursue their dreams. Thus, there’s plenty of demand to live in L.A. As a result, everything including rent, food, gas, and utilities is expensive! The average rent in Los Angeles is approximately $2,258 per month. When considering a move to L.A., the first order of business is understanding how much money it is going to take for rooms and rent in Los Angeles.

  • Average rent for 1 Bedroom Apartment in Los Angeles is $1300
  • Average rent for 2 Bedroom Apartment in Los Angeles is $2200
  • Average rent for 3 Bedroom Apartment in Los Angeles is $3300

University life in Los Angeles

Most universities in Los Angeles are like homogeneous mini towns, filled with basic amenities that support life in a community. Campus hostels and rooms for rent in Los Angeles offer economical accommodation options for students. There’s so much to do in L.A. and feels like there’s no time! There are nearly endless stretches of beaches, swathes of museums, entertainment houses, and hiking trails all across the city.

  • California Institute of Technology (Caltech)
  • University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA)
  • University of Southern California
  • Loyola Marymount University
  • California State University, Los Angeles

Related: Pet-Friendly Decor for Your Los Angeles Apartment

How transit friendly is Los Angeles?

Los Angeles is home to one of the country’s best public transportation networks. This includes subways, light-rail, buses and shuttles to nearly every corner of the Greater Los Angeles area. The Los Angeles Tourism & Convention Board is making it economical and easier than ever to discover L.A. even without having to drive.

1. Walkability in Los Angeles

Though a lot of people use cars, grocery stores, restaurants and attractions are easily accessible by foot. Which is a good thing, since gas prices average a little more than $4 a gallon. You can go on a little adventure on foot to explore the city’s cultural attractions and neighborhoods.

2. Roads & traffic in Los Angeles

Los Angeles is known for its on road way of life! Hence, traffic is usually heavy on the freeways during morning and evening commutes when you’re driving in Los Angeles. Weekday morning L.A. rush hour is roughly from 7 a.m. to 10 a.m. The evening L.A. rush hours are around 4 p.m. to 7 p.m. and later. On weekend nights, be careful of the traffic heading into or out of Downtown L.A. and Hollywood.

3. Taxis in Los Angeles

Los Angeles is huge! With its growing traffic, traveling by cab will cost you even to get to your 20 minute away studio apartment in Los Angeles. Fares are metered and vary by company. It’s recommended to request cabs over phone, though some prowl the streets late at night. You’ll see them always lined up at airports, train stations, bus stations and major hotels.

Roomi Tip: Use Uber and Lyft smartphone apps for cheaper rides in L.A.

4. Public transportation in Los Angeles

The Metro Rail and Bus System in L.A. is easy-to-use and environmentally friendly. It offers visitors a desirable and efficient way of getting from one destination to the next. All rail stations are served by Metro bus lines. Local, Rapid, Express and BRT (bus rapid transit) services are available throughout the Greater Los Angeles area. It consists of nearly 200 different lines, with buses traveling all over the region to every major destination. This includes state parks, area attractions, and shopping districts.

5. Airports in Los Angeles

There are a total of 5 airports in Los Angeles, each distinct from the other in its own way.

  • Los Angeles International Airport (LAX)
  • Hollywood Burbank Airport
  • Long Beach Airport
  • John Wayne Airport
  • Ontario International Airport (ONT)

6. Is Los Angeles cycle friendly?

L.A. used to be the worst cycling city, but it has changed significantly. It has made way for the cyclist lifestyle in several neighborhoods such as Venice, West Los Angeles and West Adams. These neighborhoods offer bike lanes, helpful routes, scenic bike paths, and even bicycle parking and amenities.

Nightlife in Los Angeles

Los Angeles sets the standard for world-class nightlife with luxurious spaces, exciting new themes and lavish décor. Apart from enjoying the skyline from studio apartments in Los Angeles at night, there are many things to do in Los Angeles. Dance clubs, live music and comedy venues, cocktail lounges and sports bars are some places to enjoy after-dark excitement in L.A.

Restaurants in Los Angeless

L.A. is so rich, with its dynamic diversity and ability to embrace wild ideas. Los Angeles is also known for it world-class brunch spots for a fulfilling memorable meal.

  • Gjusta
  • République
  • Rose Cafe
  • Guerrilla Tacos

There are only few cities in the world that can hit home runs with so many distinct cuisines, both casual and refined. And that’s the beauty of Los Angeles!
